name: Poster in agricultural exhibit, South Louisiana State Fair, Donaldsonville, Oct. 9th to 16th, 1938. The exhibits included agricultural and manufactured products, and home economics demonstrations. The posters were excellent, and showed an awareness of the problems confronting the farmers, as well as much native imagination.

description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Giant Tire MFR. A steady stream of large, rugged tires for Uncle Sam's fighting forces, like those above, is now in mass production at this large eastern plant. Here workmen are shifting newly vulcanized tires to conveyor lines that will take them to the final inspection department. They are then shipped to the fighting forces to help build the increasing number of mobile and mechanized units in America's hard-striking war machine.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Barrage Balloon Manufacture. Fin Shaping Cords- These workers are inside the rear right horizontal fin of a barrage balloon, checking the ropes which give the fin shape, and hold it together. Since barrage balloons are non-rigid and entirely collapsible, these ropes come closest to being a "back-bone" for the gigantic "defenders of cities."
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Conversion: Watch cases to War Production. Skill and experience back the production drive. A die maker in a converted Kentucky watch case factory brings rare ability to the plant's new job of making compass cases, fuze baffles, machine gun parts and other war essentials.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Conversion-Beverage Containers to Aviation Oxygen Cylinders. Removing of non-shatter-chemical solution tank at a rubber factory now producing metal essentials for the Army. This bath, which follows the removal of the weld scale, gives the inside of the cylinder a further cleaning and removes all chemicals which may remain from the previous operation. A satin-like surface, absolutely sterile and free from foreign matter, is made permanent in this operation. The cylinder is now also immune to attack from corrosion and other deteriorating elements.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Fingers of Destruction. Gauging and weighing a .50 caliber ball cartridges in an endless row. Production for National Defense is geared up to top speed at this Army arsenal.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: TVA Production: Chemical Plants. Studies in the high-pressure synthesis of gases are being made continuously in TVA chemical laboratories in the Muscle Shoals area. The plants served by these laboratories make ammonia for conversion to ammonium nitrate for use in the manufacture of high explosive shells, elemental phosphorus for the making of incendiary bombs and shells, phosphoric acid and highly concentrated phosphatic fertilizers.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Prosperous farmers lean-to construction is a common thing on midwest farm buildings, as the farmer becomes more prosperous and needs more room for his livestock. It was already a large barn on the E.H. Baird farm near Green Mountain (Marshall County) Iowa, but after the farmer had built additions on three sides there was room for hundreds of cattle. In barns like this the hay usually comes to the ground in the central part with feeding mangers running around it.
author: Harold Benzing
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Dominating almost every midwest town is its high water tank which supplies the town with gravity water pressure for drinking, sanitation and fire protection. The height of the towers, usually located on the highest hill, supplies sufficient pressure to throw water to the highest building in town in case of fire. This is Cambridge, (Store county, Iowa).

name: War Housing. Erie, PA. The entire framework, including sections for doors and windows, is fabricated horizontally. The crew working here will later move to another site and repeat the procedure. This circulation of crews who are experienced in one type of construction adds to the speed with which workers' homes are being built. Two crews of 40 men each are used to raise the stud frames of a 4 unit war-worker's home. On the project shown here, one crew started the framework at 8:30 AM fabricating it horizontally, and finished it at noon. The other crew moved in shortly after, erected the stud frames, ends and floor joints, and finished the entire framework by 4:30 PM the same day.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Negro revival meeting, La Forge, Missouri
author: Russell Lee (American, 1903–1986)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Fort Benning: Parachute Troops. Just what you thought it was. One of Uncle Sam's hardy paratroopers all set to be somewhere soon. Stand by for a minute, and we'll watch him land. He's learning the game at Fort Benning, Georgia.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Production: A-31 ("Vengeance") Dive Bombers. Motor adjustment. On top of the engine, a flight service mechanic is shown adjusting the motor on the "Vengeance" dive bomber manufactured at the Nashville Division of Vulteo Aircraft, Inc. The "Vengeance" (A-31) was originally designed for the French. It was later adopted by the R.A.F. and still later by the U.S. Army Air Forces. It is a single-engine, low-wing plane, carrying a crew of two men and having six machine guns of varying calibers.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Shipbuilding. This worker is in the plate-bender's shop, where steel plates are bent to fit the sidings of warcraft under construction. This is the operation requiring a high degree of skill.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Aluminum casting. A husky Negro workman taps a 2000 pound rotary furnace from which aluminum pours into carrying pots.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Production: A-31 ("Vengeance") Dive Bombers. Layout for control rods. One of the women employees at the Nashville Division of Vultee Aircraft, Inc. is pictured inside a tail cone which will be incorporated in a Vultee "Vengeance" dive bomber. She is checking the layout for control rods. The "Vengeance" (A-31) was originally designed for the French. It was later adopted by the R.A.F. and still later by the U.S. Army Air Forces. It is a single-engine, low-wing plane, carrying a crew of two men and having six machine guns of varying calibers.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Transformer Manufacture. For many years this employee of a large eastern electrical company has been winding low voltage coils for power transformers. He's become one of Uncle Sam's valued workers, because transformers are essential to almost every phase of the armament program.
author: Alfred T. Palmer (American, 1906–1993)
description: Henry Holmes Smith Archive, Eskenazi Museum of Art, Indiana University

name: Thirty-three acres of contour furrows constructed by hand and machine to attempt revegetation by protection from grazing and seeding furrows to sweet clover, crested wheatgrass and slender wheatgrass. Furrows were reseeded in spring of 1938 to native bunch grass, crested wheatgrass, sweet clover, Canadian wild rye, and wild blue rye. name: Lake Carrier. White-hot steel pours like water from a 35-ton electric furnace. The finest quality steels and alloys are produced in these furnaces, which allow much greater control of temperature than other conversion furnaces. The proportion of electric furnace steel is rising steadily, even though this process is the most expensive. The furnace is tilted for the pouring. The flying sparks indicate the fluidity of the steel. STILL FROM THE OEM MOTION PICTURE, "LAKE CARRIER."
